page.title: 08 LOCAL HISTORY ii
page.content: { EAST SHEEN,}like its neighbours, used to have several large houses in the 18th & 19th centuries which are now only street-names - Spencer, Deanhill, Coval.... The present development came with the railway, after 1846. The now sought-after cottages in Westfields, Derby Road etc. were built to house the workers of the market gardens. Their numbers were swelled by Irishmen fleeing the Potato Famine and the RC Church of St.Mary Magdalene was built for them. The Cambridge & Oxford boat race is run from Putney to Mortlake. The first race was run in 1856,then annually except during the Wars. It no longer attracts the huge crowds it did, but receives worldwide TV coverage. A week later, since 1926, on the same stretch, over 300 eights compete in the Head of the River Race.
